patient_information: A 52-year-old man with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and poorly controlled hypertension.
history_of_present_illness: The patient presented to an urban hospital in Ho Chi Minh City with a four-day history of retro-orbital headache, lethargy, myalgia, and fevers. The fevers had reportedly begun to improve over the 24 hours prior to presentation.
exposure_and_epidemiology: The patient lives in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam, a high-endemicity area for dengue. His last travel outside the city was several years ago. The text notes that the risk of malaria is very low in most urban areas of Vietnam and the absence of suspected rodent exposure makes leptospirosis less likely.
vitals: On examination, the patient's temperature was 36.5°C, blood pressure was 105/90 mmHg, heart rate was 120 bpm, and respiratory rate was 28 breaths per minute. His peripheral oxygen saturation was 93% on air. His Glasgow Coma Score (GCS) was 14/15.
physical_exam: The patient was drowsy but rousable with a weak radial pulse but normal heart sounds. Respiratory examination revealed a dull percussion note and reduced breath sounds at both lung bases. The abdomen was mildly distended with shifting dullness and a tender liver edge palpable 3cm below the costal margin. Skin examination was unremarkable.
labs_and_diagnostics: Laboratory results on admission showed haemoconcentration (Haematocrit 53.9%), thrombocytopenia (Platelets 58 ×10^9/L), and leukopenia (WCC 2.1 ×10^9/L) with both neutropenia and lymphopenia. C-reactive protein was 20 mg/L, and lactate was elevated at 3.5 mmol/L. Liver function tests were deranged with an ALT of 812 U/L. Ultrasound scans confirmed moderate bilateral pleural effusions, ascites, mild hepatomegaly, and a thickened gallbladder wall. A subsequent haematocrit rose to 55.1%. The diagnosis was confirmed by a positive reverse transcriptase PCR (RT-PCR) and a positive NS1 ELISA.
differential_diagnosis: The main differential diagnosis was dengue infection progressing to severe disease, which was considered typical given the clinical picture and high-endemicity area. Other considerations included rickettsial infections like scrub typhus. Malaria was considered, but the risk was low in urban Vietnam and there was no evidence of haemolysis. Leptospirosis was also a possibility, but less likely without a history of rodent exposure. Melioidosis was also considered in the context of a diabetic patient from Southeast Asia with possible sepsis.
management_and_clinical_course: The patient was diagnosed with compensated shock and admitted to a high-dependency unit for close observation and supportive care. He was managed with careful fluid resuscitation using Ringer's lactate, starting at 10mL/kg/hr and increasing to 15mL/kg/hr due to persistent tachycardia, oliguria, and a rising haematocrit. The fluid rate was subsequently tapered as his condition improved. Clinical status and haematocrit were monitored frequently. The patient made a complete recovery and was discharged from the hospital 3 days later.
final_diagnosis: The final diagnosis is severe dengue with compensated shock. This was confirmed by reverse transcriptase PCR (RT-PCR) and a positive NS1 ELISA test. The diagnosis is supported by the typical clinical progression from a febrile illness to a critical phase with signs of shock (tachycardia, narrow pulse pressure), laboratory evidence of haemoconcentration and severe thrombocytopenia, and ultrasound findings demonstrating vascular leakage (pleural effusions, ascites).
